fr:mainmatter.fr:p: PhD student at Royal Holloway, University of London researching programming language semantics via cyclic proof theory, type theory, and category theory. Supervised by Reuben Rowe.
Senior Lecturer in Computer Science at Royal Holloway, University of London.
A monad T is idempotent when T \eta = \eta T, which for monad containers immediately gives us \iota = s for all s : S, and hence S is contractible.

fr:title.text: All affine monad containers are representable

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: All affine monad containers are representable

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a commutative monad container. By taking the categorical definition of affine monads and specialising it to monad container extensions, we get for all a, b : S the equation: \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . b) = a Since we have a point \iota : S, we can conclude that S is contractible. Hence we have that S \triangleright P is 1 \triangleright \lambda \_ . P\ \iota .

Let (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a monad container. We call the monad container commutative when the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . b) &= \sigma \ b\ (\lambda \_ . a)\\ \text {pr}_1\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ p\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_1\ p \end {align*} The laws for \text {pr} hold given the first law. Commutative monad containers interpret exactly the commutative monads for container functors.

Earlier this week Stef and I were working on the monad container distributive law project. We had a very insightful meeting with Dan Marsden who mentioned (among other things) that we should look for applications for our characterisation. Things to try:
Find characterisations for tighter classes of monad containers (i.e. commutative, affine, relevant) and see if this simplifies the distributive law. We have already characterised distributive laws for cartesian monad containers for example.
Prove more than just mere existence of distributive laws - use the characterisation to find exactly how many there are for a given pair of monad containers.
Over-approximate distributive law requirements to have an easier time with the above. For example, we could consider when the position map v is just \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , which often seems to be the case in simpler examples.
Find which algebraic theories correspond to container monads, to tie our work to Maaike Zwart and Dan's work on distributive laws for algebraic theories.

Let S \triangleright P be a container. A mnd-container (or monad container) on S \triangleright P is given by the following data: \begin {align*} \iota &: S\\ \sigma &: \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to S) \to S\\ \text {pr} &: \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to S\}} P\ (\sigma \ s\ f) \to \sum _{p : P\ s} P\ (f\ p) \end {align*} For which the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . a ) &= a\\ \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ) &= a\\ \sigma \ (\sigma \ a\ f)\ (\lambda p . g\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\ (\text {pr}_2\ p)) &= \sigma \ a\ (\lambda p . \sigma \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p))\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_1\ p) &= \text {pr}_1\ p\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) \end {align*} We abbreviate \pi _1 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_1 and \pi _2 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_2. The last three laws hold up the "associativity" law for \sigma .
\mu HOL^{ex} is a proof system that I've been developing for part of my PhD project with my supervisor Reuben Rowe.

The goal is to develop a proof system for higher-order logic with fixed-point operators, that allows for induction and coinduction by adding fixed-point "unfolding" rules, and allowing proofs to be cyclic.

Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as Set functors are monads.

This characterisation is useful for enumerating all possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.
